parameter 1: According to the book, The Bond Files, the film was never shown with anything other than the Peter Sellers in Paris opening sequence. It's possible the gunbarrel parody if filmed was removed before general release.
parameter 2: In the Region 2 DVD which has English, German, French, Italian and Spanish audio tracks, the ending is left instrumental in Spanish audio track unlike the others.
parameter 3: The R1 DVD version now has the MGM logo at the begining instead of the columbia logo like in all other prints
parameter 4: According to the book, The Bond Files, the film was never shown with anything other than the Peter Sellers in Paris opening sequence. It's possible the gunbarrel parody if filmed was removed before general release.
parameter 5: There are two network television versions: the original 3-hour theatrical cut minus objectionable footage, and a re-edited 140 minute version put together under sole supervision of original director Martin Scorsese.
parameter 6: In the Region 2 DVD which has English, German, French, Italian and Spanish audio tracks, the ending is left instrumental in Spanish audio track unlike the others.
parameter 7: According to the book, The Bond Files, the film was never shown with anything other than the Peter Sellers in Paris opening sequence. It's possible the gunbarrel parody if filmed was removed before general release.
parameter 8: The version shown in Swedish cinemas in 1996 removed 43 meters of footage (the vice torture and baseball beatings).
parameter 9: Contemporary reviews of this film mention an opening sequence that spoofs the Bond films' "gunbarrel" opening, only instead of us hearing a gunshot, we hear a popping cork. Perhaps it was thought to be too similar to the opening of the regular Bond films, because TV and video prints instead use a short Peter Sellers sequence from the middle of the film as the "teaser."
parameter 10: The version shown in Swedish cinemas in 1996 removed 43 meters of footage (the vice torture and baseball beatings).
parameter 11: The version shown in Swedish cinemas in 1996 removed 43 meters of footage (the vice torture and baseball beatings).
parameter 12: Finnish VHS release is cut by 1 minute. Notable cuts were: - Tony Dogs being tortured with the vice - Baseball bat killings

parameter 17: In 2007, Kino International Corp. copyrighted a 20-second surviving fragment of the film, with a new piano music score composed and performed by 'Ben Model' (qv).

parameter 25: The R1 DVD version now has the MGM logo at the begining instead of the columbia logo like in all other prints
parameter 26: A short version of "Casino Royale" is regularly shown on Swiss television. This cut, approx. 93 minutes long, is reformatted in 1.85/1 ratio. In this shorter version, many scene have been cut, like the car chase between David Niven and the girls. The scene between Peter Sellers and Ursula Andress has been shortened. The "look of love" part is not in this version, like the "dreaming scene" when Peter dreams that he makes love to Ursula. In the Berlin sequence too, the version of "What's New Pussycat?" that the protagonist hears when they open the sewer is different.
parameter 27: In the Region 2 DVD, in the French audio track, the music bit before end credits is dubbed in French.
parameter 28: The version shown in Swedish cinemas in 1996 removed 43 meters of footage (the vice torture and baseball beatings).
